item.title: Java conventions for curly bracket placement
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

I prefer the second one. I feel it gives me more ability to easily see what is actually inside the method; I can just go down until I find a closing brace on the same line.

because you are?[/quote]
l m f a o

i prefer the first one

item.title: Java conventions for curly bracket placement
item.dc:creator: @Techkid Techkid
item.description:
@Techkid wrote:

[quote=“ravekitty, post:1, topic:535371”]I was just wondering… Do you prefer to have your method curly braces like this

void methodName() {
//code
}

Which one would you find easier to read?
Is there any reason I should or shouldn’t use either of the two?[/quote]
I find the first one easier to read because it looks better with the parameters. The other one would make me struggle with coding because i would have to purposing stop to make that. I’m pretty sure in eclipse if you press CTRL+SHIFT+O it puts it like the first one.

Read full topic
item.source: Java conventions for curly bracket placement

item.title: Java conventions for curly bracket placement
item.dc:creator: @artem543 artem543
item.description:
@artem543 wrote:

Yz85Racer:

I always preferred to have the brace on the same line in Java, but on a different line for C/++

SAME! Seriously, it just looks more neat when it is on one line. Specially when you have 200 of those brackets, it makes 200 more lines.

Read full topic
item.source: Java conventions for curly bracket placement

item.title: Java conventions for curly bracket placement
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:7, topic:535371”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=654176.msg4382206#msg4382206 date=1383948524]
I use both ({ on same line for Java, { on next line for C/C++). It really depends first on preference, second on the recommended conventions of the language (if any), and third on the conventions used by any programmers you look up to in that particular language (particularly helpful if you are unsure which to use).
[/quote]I’d say the most important conventions to follow are whatever the project is already using (if you’re working on an existing one).[/quote]

It depends on who’s directing the tech of the project and their guidelines on whether you can choose your own conventions or follow already outlined conventions. I intentionally left that out since it’s not as relevant of a detail for the majority of the people at this community.

Read full topic

item.title: Java conventions for curly bracket placement
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:7, topic:535371”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=654176.msg4382206#msg4382206 date=1383948524]
I use both ({ on same line for Java, { on next line for C/C++). It really depends first on preference, second on the recommended conventions of the language (if any), and third on the conventions used by any programmers you look up to in that particular language (particularly helpful if you are unsure which to use).
[/quote]I’d say the most important conventions to follow are whatever the project is already using (if you’re working on an existing one).[/quote]

It is unlikely that some hipster would be working on a bigger multi-person project. Hipsters be coding proof-of-concept basic calculator apps and console number guessing games in as many hipster languages as possible.

Anyway, about the brace style. Boss Nigga be enforcing his own brace style whenever he wants, other niggas be following.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“runeite51, post:11, topic:535371”]I prefer the first one. The way I see it, putting the first bracket on a new line doesn’t make it any more organized, so why waste an extra line on it?[/quote]readability of the underlying scopes. that’s one advantage i like to see in the new lined braces

Read full topic

It really depends first on preference, second on the recommended conventions of the language (if any), and third on the conventions used by any programmers you look up to in that particular language (particularly helpful if you are unsure which to use).

item.source: Java conventions for curly bracket placement

item.title: Java conventions for curly bracket placement
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

The official Java conventions by Oracle recommend the following style:

The opening brace should be at the end of the line that begins the compound statement; the closing brace should begin a line and be indented to the beginning of the compound statement.
Open brace "{" appears at the end of the same line as the declaration statement

http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/documentation/codeconventions-142311.html#15395
http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/documentation/codeconventions-141270.html#381

Read full topic
